title: Does it crack you up when you see scientists 'discover' something that was there all along? How much more of what we think we know do we not know? What else do we have wrong? - Quora

response.answer_text: First, a quick review of the meaning of the word “discover”: From Dictionary.com - The world’s favorite online dictionary! Discover To see, get knowledge of, learn of, find, or find out; gain sight or knowledge of (something previously unseen or unknown) I’m sort of a “rock hound.” I’ve discovered many interesting rocks in my life. Some real, actual Indian arrow heads, several nice chunks of petrified “wood”, and a very, very cool fossil of part of a creature, that has perplexed me for a few years now. Here’s what that looks like:  Now, I know just enough about fossils, to know that I know nothing about fossils. But I did spend some time on the web, searching in various ways, and at some point I found something like this:  and I thought .oO{Well, that seems like a pretty good bet} and based on that brilliant piece of “cell phone sleuthing” I decided that what I most likely had was a fragment from the outer spiral of an ammonite. One of these:  Sweet right? Well, not so fast. Upon further examination using a common cheap magnifying glass and my fifty-three year old eyes, and also having had it occur to me to flip the damn thing over !! I found this:  (Okay, yes, I added the little inset drawing, and now I’ve biased you, sorry.) When I first noticed this little formation, for some reason my mind instantly thought “vertebra.” I guess if you watch enough science shows, some part of your brain retains—something. So I went out and started looking at drawings of vertebra on the web until my eyes started to glaze over. They come in countless varieties, and they vary within a single organism also, depending on where they are located on the spine. Also, they get deformed during the MILLIONS OF YEARS they spend becoming—rocks. But !!! If that is actually what this is, then no, this is not an ammonite. Can you guess why not? Exactly ! So what the hell is it? Have I actually discovered a fossilized fragment of the neck of some vertebrate animal, lying in a pile of rocks beside a stream in the Swiss Alps? I believe there’s a good possibility that I have. I don’t have the arrow heads handy or I would paste in a few shots of those. At least on those, which I found in my yard in Texas, I can easily say that “Yes, these are—or were intended to turn out to be—arrowheads” and also that they were almost certainly made by aboriginal people who once lived, well, in my front yard, or close by anyway. I promise you though, even thought I certainly did “discover” them, I did not invent, create, or otherwise call them into existence. Most of them were literally just laying around waiting to be discovered. A few were a foot or two beneath the surface of my front yard, and I discovered them while digging trenches for sprinkler pipes. Some of the failed arrow heads were, I kid you not, lying on the ground at the storage place where I keep my boat. Every time I go there, I spend as much time staring at the rocks on the ground as I do stowing/retrieving the boat, and I always find something. In that case, the “rocks” covering the premises have obviously been dumped and spread out to form a surface for people to drive and park boats on. I don’t know where they came from originally, but I’m pretty sure that it wasn’t too far away from where I live either. I love the way that the definition at the top of this answer says “something previously unseen or unknown.” I choose, with my “rocks” to interpret that as though the words “by me” were appended to the end. Also, it’s neat, with fossils and arrowheads, knowing that it is quite possible that I really am the first person to see it, ever! (fossils) or since it was discarded (arrowheads.) In case it isn’t clear, when you find arrow heads “in the wild”, what you almost always are actually discovering is things that someone threw away because they were trying to make it into an arrow head and screwed it up. I wonder what those guys/gals would have thought if they had known how worked up some old geezer, hundreds, maybe thousands of years later would get, when he happened across their fails? Once, on an isolated beach on Oahu Hawaii, I discovered a very corroded shell casing. I’d be willing to bet that it was fired from the gun mounted on a Japanese Zero, back on December 7th, 1941. I think it’s plausible; and if it’s true, then when I picked it up and looked at it, I was probably the first person to actually look, specifically at it, since the day that it was manufactured in Japan, (or wherever they made bullets that zero’s shot while invading Pearl Harbor, probably years before the invasion. Honestly, in my experience, discovering the things that are hiding in plain sight, right in front of your nose (or toes), is a lot harder than many people realize. Hearing about it doesn’t crack me up, it fires me up—with enthusiasm !! P.S. If you don’t think that I actually answered the question then, well . . . “yer a towel . . .”

Expansionism. It’s based on a mis-attribution of observed red shift. It was attributed to the Doppler effect which would mean galaxies are receding from us observers. The observed red shift is uniform in all directions which appears to mean we are at the center of that putative expansion. That’s absurd, and even more absurd was the explanation of expanding membranes to try to account for that absurdity of geocentric expansion. The model of an inflating balloon was used to explain center-less expansion. However, the dots on the balloon which represent the galaxies on the expanding membranes expand along with the balloon membranes and of course no one has reported galaxies or anything else expanding, just space-time (ST) expands but not the stuff stuck to it. Absurd. 20 years ago some comparative calculations were made on the observed red shift and sticking with expansionism, attributed those numbers to accelerating expansion called inflation. Ultra absurd. There’s a very simple, easy to understand alternative to uniform red shift: curvature. ST is curved. ST is never flat. There’s nothing in GR, the context in which ST operates, that insists the baseline resting state of ST must be Euclidean (flat). Euclidean geometry applies to space, not ST which is Riemannian, the geometry of curvature which gave birth to GR with ST as the core concept of GR. We should refer to ST as Riemannian ST (RST) to clarify that Euclidean geometry plays no role in GR. Red shift is routinely observed in the deeper curvature of RST near massive bodies. What is being observed from distant galaxies where there are no massive bodies nearby to induce deeper curvature in RST is the red shift currently mis-attributed to Doppler effect. What about the cosmic background radiation (CBR) currently attributed to being the aftermath “echo” of the putative BB? Well, in a universe of RST where ST is inherently curved, starlight has eternity to circulate around and around until it degrades in frequency all the way down to microwaves and radiowaves. No, it makes me think that that is science, doing its job. The whole point of science is discovery and explanation. And while discoveries are increasingly about more and more exotic things, we still have a lot to learn about stuff that is right in front of us (or inside us), so every so often we will realise that we have to view something familiar in a new light. As Isaac Asimov put it, the most exciting words in science are not “Eureka!” but “That’s funny…” It’s when we notice something that doesn’t fit with our current understanding that we learn something new - and in this case, the insight that underlies reclassifying the interstitium as previously unrecognised organ may have genuinely huge and positive ramifications. If it does turn out that that is how cancer cells spread, we may be able to devise a more effective mechanism to stop metastasis, and prevent thousands of painful deaths to cancer every year. That would be huge in terms of reducing human suffering (though it will also present new challenges to our economic and societal systems in terms of rebalancing the age profile of our populations). The great scientific revolutions have come from seeing what is already there in a different light: Newton realised from the fall of an apple that there was a universal law of how things fall towards one anotherDarwin developed the theory of evolution by natural selection from decades of painstaking observation of differences between speciesPlanck developed quantization while trying to explain why a heated black body does not emit an infinite amount of ultraviolet radiationEinstein developed his theories of relativity from the observations that the speed of light appeared to be constant and that a body in free fall would be indistinguishable in its own frame of reference from one at rest.Fleming identified penicillin from noticing that mould on an agar plate prevented bacteria from growing around it.This interstitium discovery is not on the level of the first four, but it might in time rival penicillin for its public health impact. There was nothing special about these observations, Everyone has seen things fall. The changes in speciation that Darwin saw were there for anyone with the time and patience to catalogue. The Black Body Problem and Michelson-Morley Experiement were well known puzzles for physicist. Penicillium mould was nothing new. The interstitium had been seen before - just not recognised for what it was. What was new in each case was the insight about what it meant. As to how much more we do not know, there is plenty more to be discovered, especially in fields outside the hard sciences like biology, physiology and psychology. Last year there were around 250,000 new doctorates issued worldwide (These countries have the most doctoral graduates) - and each one by definition involved original research. Some of those will have been confirming or retesting existing findings. Many of them will have edged the boundaries of established theories a little further forward. But a handful will have sown the seeds of a revolution in our knowledge. And that is a cause for excitement, rather than despair or mockery. Because that is exactly what science exists to do.

No. Because the version you see in newspaper and non-specialist blogs is often so heavily simplified as to be pretty useless, horribly inaccurate or both. Few news sites have dedicated science writers any more - a person with both academic and actual experience working in a real scientific industry. This means your science reporting goes: Scientist > Academic Publisher > PR Agency Writer > Newspaper Writer > Newspaper Editor > You Unfortunately, the PR agency probably don’t understand the original research paper very well, and pick out a handful of key points they think will generate interest. The newspaper writer does not even read the original paper, but takes one minor point from the PR, and makes it all about that. The editor takes the article and adds an attention grabbing (nut inaccurate) headline. This means a complex scientific research project like ‘Understanding human growth rates based on parental pre-natal diet in developed countries’ ends up being a headline ‘EAT BANANAS OR YOUR BABY WILL DIE’ (I made these up, but it’s pretty typical. See: Daily Mail health reporting.) Scientists work off grants and funding. To get grants, they usually have to show the research topic is at least reasonably novel, or there are gaps in current understanding. Even if the research confirms what we already believe, the very act of doing this is highly useful. Science relies on proof. TL;DR : Read the original paper. There’s a lot more in there.

Huh? Gravity has always been part of the human existence. Scientists did not discover gravity; the apple did not fall on Newton's head and he suddenly realized, “Hey, gravity! How did we miss that?” Newton figured the rules for gravity and how it affected planetary orbits. Einstein refined the rules. He didn't discover gravity. Sometimes scientists do discover things that we did not know existed. We knew earthquakes happened, but plate tectonics was not obvious. It was not something that we “always knew.” So I don't think your question is particularly useful. It assumes something that doesn't have a basis in fact, and it smacks of anti-intellectualism.

Discovery is not just the fact that something existed - but also what the implications are of the purpose and function of these things . Humans have been observing sunlight ever since their eyes could function. But what is light made of ? Why does it burn ? How is it made ? How do we “see” ? How do plants convert it’s energy ? These are all questions about easily observable “features” of light. But actually understanding the reasons and functions behind it are several lifetimes of work for very clever people. And yes, there are “heaps” of things we think we know, that we don't. Any sensible and educated person should be totally aware of the problem, its just part of the scientific method.

The common meaning of the word discover is to find something that existed before the person found out about it so there is no problem with someone says that a scientist, or anyone else for that matter, saying that a scientist discovered something. Science, and other empirical disciplines, are in the business of discovering the truth about our universe and its inhabitants. The notion that there is something suspect about their discovering it a little at a time is just a reflection of the notion that religion has the truth without any investigation or evidence. Often religious apologists challenge science this way because they are uncomfortable with the concept that their religion doesn’t know anything about the truth.

I’m interested in how you think anyone might “discover” something that had not “been there all along”. In answer to your only actual question, it is the assumption of scientists that we have everything wrong in some limit or circumstances; our passion is searching for where our present theories fail. You really have no idea what science is about, do you?

Not at all. It’s a process of successive approximation. We’ve learnt a lot, there will always be more to learn, but no one can deny we’ve made progress, else, for example, you’d be trying desperately trying to use smoke signals to post your question, instead of digitally via the Net from a PC or electronic tablet conceived and constructed ultimately from our scientific knowledge. Look at what we’ve got right, and what else there’s to do.

“What else do we have wrong?” Wow. That is an incredibly deep and weighted question. Much of it, no, all of it, is merely programming. Lets just put it this way. Roughly 91% of all the history you have been taught in school is misleading, and partially, or completely wrong. How much of what you were taught from 1st grade to college do you use in your every day life? Once a year? Ever? Nuff said.

What cracks me up is that anyone would think Teen Vogue is a source of breaking science news. Everything the article describes is very old news, and not paradigm-changing. Interstitial fluid is a very old discovery. The interstitium is just the collection of spaces between cells. Calling it an organ is an exercise in semantics, not an anatomical discovery.

No. I'm fascinated. Everything science has ever discovered has been there all along. There always has to be someone to describe it first. As to what fraction of unknowns are unknown unknowns…that's a known unknown that we know is impossible to know. As for what has been described in scientific literature.. .we can be quite sure that at least 5% of it is wrong. I'd personally stake a claim to 30%.

Gravity has always been in existence. Galileo did some serious thinking. Newton put the "icing on the cake"! Then Einstein put a cherry and chocolate sprinkles in the icing. Does it crack me up? No: I deeply respect their observation, their mathematical rigour, their ability to explain natural phenomenon!

We know we do not know somethings . Other things we do not know what we do not know . Scientifc verification does not crack me up . It tests assumptions, it may be counterintuitive . in 1900 , there was consideration of closing the US patent office on the grounds that everything had been invented . Our minds always need to be open .

“Discover“ means finding something that was there all along. That’s how scientists work - some postulate theories, others work on disproving them, some just look for things that others might have missed. Some of it is just wrong, and someone else will prove that. History of plate tectonics

Yes. So many scientific study results are incredibly obvious. “Studies show that people who live in impoverished and violent areas have higher levels of PTSD than those who do not.” YOU DON’T SAY? I could have told you that. Have a look around.
Point of terminological and historical order here: most all discoveries are of things, or places or phenomena that were there all along. That’s why we spend so much time searching.
What else do we have wrong? Why, almost EVERYTHING. But our theories about how things work are getting better even though none of them will probably ever be ‘complete’.
Yes, it really does. Or when they suddenly change their mind about stuff like: “Cholesterol is bad! No it's good! No it's bad!”. Whatever.
Well, I never knew Teen Vogue existed. Now I do. But I’m not a scientist, so I guess that doesn’t count.
I think we probably need better definitions for Science and Scientist.
